docs.lead_paragraph: The Equitable Life Assurance Society , the world's oldest customer-owned insurer, said today that it would not seek new business after an unsuccessful six-month search for a buyer. Equitable Life put itself up for sale in July after the House of Lords, the highest court in England and Wales, issued a ruling that the company had unlawfully cut bonuses to some policyholders. The ruling left the 238-year-old Equitable owing at least $:1.5 billion ($2.2 billion) to holders of policies with guaranteed annuities.

headline.main: Equitable of Britain to Cease Taking New Business

docs.abstract: Equitable Life Assurance Society, world's oldest customer-owned insurer, announces that it will not seek new business in Great Britain; firm has sought buyer during past six months; House of Lords issued ruling that will cost Equitable at least $2.2 billion, severely crippling its finances (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-22 U.S. and Russia Seek Tough Sanctions on Taliban The United States and Russia asked the Security Council to toughen and broaden sanctions against the Taliban government in Afghanistan. The Russians and Americans are concerned about the Taliban's influence and its support for Muslim militants and international terrorists. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: Congressional leaders met again today with President Clinton and said they had made modest progress toward a budget agreement that would permit the 106th Congress to finish its work and adjourn for the year. After the hourlong session, Jake Siewert, the White House press secretary, said: ''The meeting helped narrow some differences. But there are still significant differences, especially on education.''

headline.main: Clinton and Republicans Gain on Spending Accord

docs.abstract: Congressional leaders meet again with Pres Clinton and report modest progress toward budget agreement that would permit Congress to adjourn; photo (M)
